awd_titl_txt: Two Dimensional TeraHertz Spectroscopy of Molecular Liquids
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure Dynamics and Mechanism A (CSDM-A) and Chemical Measurement and Imaging (CMI) Programs of the Chemistry Division, Professors Geoffrey Blake and Tom Miller of the California Institute of Technology are using new laser techniques to study the properties of pure molecular liquids and mixtures, especially those containing hydrogen bonds (for example water and alcohols). Specifically, the new laser tools involve light at terahertz (THz) frequencies (this frequency range lies between the infrared and microwave parts of the light spectrum).  These THz lasers are also designed to produce extremely short pulses of light (a few femtoseconds, where a femtosecond is one quadrillionth of one second).  The femtosecond THz laser pulses are then used to probe the motions of the liquid molecules as they interact with other reactive molecules dissolved in the liquid. The THz pulses also make it possible to control the orientation of the molecules in the liquid, and to examine how energy flows between two reacting molecules or between the molecules and the liquid. Professors Blake and Miller combine the experimental data with computer simulations of liquids and clusters of molecules to build better models for understanding chemical reactions in liquids. The broader impacts of this work include potential societal benefits from an increased understanding of how liquids solvate molecules and influence chemical reactivity, as well as opportunities for the training of graduate students and undergraduates in the design and construction of advanced experimental instrumentation and complex computer simulation.  The Blake and Miller research groups also engage the local K-12 community, for example via the Caltech Pre-College Science Initiative (CAPSI) program (Prof. Blake) and Prof. Miller's Team Research yielding Integrated Educational Tools (TRIDENT) program.

The project focuses on the nonlinear THz spectroscopy of neat liquids and mixtures at various temperatures. Detailed molecular pictures of the structure and dynamics of liquids drive our understanding of chemistry and biology. Nonlinear two dimensional (2D)-infrared and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopies have revealed many specifics of liquid behavior. Extending such tools into the THz regime would directly probe liquid dynamics supported by intermolecular forces. This research project does so by combining two intense THz pulses whose arrival at the sample can be swept over controlled delays, with the subsequent anisotropy and Raman spectrum of the liquid probed by a third pulse at 800 nm.  By mapping out the liquid response over the relative delays between the three pulses, a 2D-THz-THz-Raman (2D-TTR) spectrum is obtained. This method inherently suppresses the linear response of the system, and so is sensitive to anharmonicities in the intermolecular liquid potential energy surface and the electric dipole moment and Raman polarizability surfaces.  To determine the origins of the observed response, the experimental observations are interpreted with theoretical calculations both of molecular clusters and liquid models. The cluster work involves high accuracy electronic structure calculations, while the liquid simulations are based on molecular dynamics approaches.

por.por_cntn:
In molecular materials, think liquids such as water or alcohol, or ices - wet or dry (water or carbon dioxide), the vibrational modes of the individual molecules occur in the infrared (IR) region of the electromagnetic spectrum. However, the forces that dictate the behavior of the liquid or material occur between molecules, and are key to fundamental processes such as how other species are dissolved in liquids (the process of solvation), the behavior of proteins and nucleic acids, and key technological processes such as solar energy conversion. Because they are weaker forces than those which generate chemical bonds, the important spectral window to study such intermolecular forces is called the far-IR, or TeraHertz (THz) region.

The THz spectra of condensed phases can be quite complex, with broad, overlapping peaks in the linear, or absorbance data. With NSF support, we have worked to pioneer nonlinear THz spectroscopic tools, where multiple pulses of THz (and other wavelength) light are used to selectively excite, manipulate, and probe the intermolecular degrees of freedom. Such tools have been developed for vibrations and electronic transitions, but are in their infancy for THz science. Indeed, this regime is very different from that in nonlinear IR spectroscopy, due to the short pulse and broad frequency content of THz pulses. Thus, our early work in this program was to establish the 'rules of the game' - what possible mechanisms govern the interaction of high intensity THz light with liquids and molecular solids? Can we adapt the pulse shapes to optimize one path over another? Can we use the pulses to drive interesting molecular behavior? How do we optimize the experimental capabilities at THz frequencies, and what theoretical tools need to be developed to analyze the complex experimental data?

In this work we have generated among the strongest THz pulses ever reported, and used them to obtain the first nonlinear THz signatures of liquids such as halogenated methanes, water and alcohols, and self-assembled materials such as organohalide perovskites. Along the way, we have developed and described for other novel instruments that can analyze both liquids and molecular clusters held together by hydrogen bonds at the low temperatures enabled by what are called supersonic beam techniques. We have also developed state-of-the-art theoretical approaches that can analyze both classical and quantum mechanical interactions in liquids. The latter are key to the behavior of liquid water, for example. In all cases, our work is described in peer-reviewed publications and detailed descriptions of the experiments or theoretical software available on the Internet.

The many students trained in this program, both graduate and undergraduate, have also been extensively involved in education and outreach activities, especially in Caltech programs that seek to enhance diversity and equity in STEM education, and the P.I. and group regularly give public seminars on the research supported by the NSF.
